research_scope: Building codes, insurance regulations, and industry standards for roofing in Virginia, Maryland, and Pennsylvania as of October 2025

codes.description: 2021 USBC compliance became mandatory January 18, 2025. All new permits after this date must use 2021 code.
key_requirements: Based on 2021 International Codes (I-Codes) including IRC
Permits filed before January 17, 2025 may remain subject to 2018 edition

codes.description: Ice barrier requirements in areas with history of ice damming
key_requirements: Required in areas designated in Table R301.2 with ice damming history
Must consist of two layers of cemented underlayment OR self-adhering polymer-modified bitumen sheet
Must extend minimum 24 inches inside exterior wall line
For roofs 8:12 pitch or steeper: minimum 36 inches measured along roof slope from eave edge
Note: Not all VA jurisdictions require ice barriers - check local amendments

codes.description: Requirements for re-roofing and roof recover
key_requirements: Metal panel, metal shingle, concrete and clay tile may be installed over wood shake roofs per R908.4
Roof recover NOT permitted if existing roof is water-soaked or deteriorated
Roof recover NOT permitted over slate, clay, cement, or asbestos-cement tile
Slopes between 2:12 and 4:12 require double underlayment per Table R905.1.1(2)
New protective roof coating permitted over existing coatings without tear-off

codes.description: Virginia-specific alterations to IRC for existing buildings
key_requirements: Materials and methods must comply with Chapter 15 of VCC
Exception: Low-slope roof replacement not required to meet 2% minimum slope if positive drainage provided

maryland.state_framework: Each jurisdiction uses same IBC/IRC/IECC edition with state modifications

insurance_regulations.title: Cancellations, Nonrenewals, and Claim Denials Based on Satellite and Aerial Imagery
key_provisions: Addresses use of drone/aerial imaging for roofing assessments
Regulates use of AI vs. human review in risk assessments
Confirms aerial imagery collection is legal with limitations
Protects against improper cancellations based solely on imagery
insurance_regulations.impact_on_roofing: Critical for homeowners facing cancellations/denials based on roof condition assessments from aerial imagery

insurance_regulations.title: Cancellation of Life & Health and Property & Casualty Insurance Policies Due to Non-Payment of Premium
Cancellation of Insurance Policies
key_provisions: General guidance on policy cancellation procedures

insurance_regulations.title: Unfair Claim Settlement Practices
key_provisions: Prohibits refusing to pay claims for arbitrary or capricious reasons
Requires good faith in settling claims
Part of Title 27 - Unfair Trade Practices and Other Prohibited Practices
Applies to property damage claims including roofing
insurance_regulations.note: No specific 2025 amendments found; statute continues to apply to roofing matching disputes

key_requirements: Roofs must have slopes directing water to drains/gutters
All materials must be asbestos-free
Must meet local wind speed resistance standards (especially coastal areas)
Must meet fire resistance standards
Local jurisdictions may modify codes (except IECC and MAC)

matching_requirements.status: No specific state bulletin on matching found as of October 2025
matching_requirements.note: Previous reference to Bulletin 18-23 not confirmed in 2025 sources
matching_requirements.practical_application: Matching disputes resolved under general unfair claims practices law

pennsylvania.important_note: IRC cannot be enforced 'as-is' - numerous PA-specific modifications exist
pennsylvania.exemptions: Philadelphia and Allegheny County use custom codes

key_requirements: When existing roof has TWO OR MORE layers, complete removal required

New covering may be installed over old if: (1) following approved manufacturer instructions, OR (2) using complete separate system (e.g., standing-seam metal) that transmits loads directly to structure
Maximum two layers of roofing material permitted

codes.section: R905.2.5 - Fastener Requirements for Asphalt Shingles
codes.description: Nailing requirements for asphalt shingle installation
key_requirements: Fasteners must be: galvanized, stainless steel, aluminum, or copper roofing nails
Minimum 12-gauge (0.105 inch / 2.67mm) shank
Minimum 3/8-inch diameter (9.5mm) head
Must comply with ASTM F1667
Penetration: minimum 3/4 inch into roof sheathing (or through sheathing if less than 3/4 inch thick)
Minimum per manufacturer requirements
Not less than four fasteners per strip shingle
Not less than two fasteners per individual shingle
Special requirements for slopes exceeding 21:12 - follow manufacturer specs

review_process.description: PA codes updated every 3 years following ICC code releases
review_process.process: Review & Advisory Council (RAC) reviews changes and recommends inclusions/exclusions
review_process.note: Legislative exclusions and exemptions modify standard IRC provisions

pennsylvania.next_update: Triennial UCC update in process as of July 2025, publication expected fall 2025

key_points: Warranties VOID if not installed per GAF printed application instructions
WindProven warranty requires strict adherence to application instructions
Contractor must register warranty within 45 days of installation
Registration completed online by contractor, warranty emailed to homeowner by GAF

Strong community reputation and timely payments

Conditional on proper installation per GAF specifications

nrca.publication: NRCA Roofing Manual: Steep-slope Roof Systems—2025

changes: INCREASED minimum plywood thickness for asphalt shingle, metal shingle, wood shake/shingle:
16-inch rafter spacing: 1/2 inch → 5/8 inch nominal thickness
24-inch rafter spacing: 5/8 inch → 3/4 inch nominal thickness
Revised OSB panel recommendations for steep-slope roof decks
NOW RECOMMENDED for all eaves and exposed rakes on:
- Clay and concrete tile roof systems
- Wood shake and shingle roof systems
References IBC 2024 and IRC 2024 wind resistance provisions
Updated wind design maps based on ASCE 7-22
New recommendations for other-than-wood roof deck materials
New nailing substrate material recommendations for steep-slope applications

manual_series: Metal Panel and SPF Roof Systems—2024
Architectural Metal Flashing and Condensation Control—2022

fortified_home.program: FORTIFIED Home™ by IBHS (Insurance Institute for Business & Home Safety)

major_2025_changes.change: All FORTIFIED roofs MUST be installed by certified FORTIFIED roofing contractors (NEW requirement)
Inland requirements now more consistent with hurricane-prone areas
specifics: All FORTIFIED roof decks require tighter nailing pattern (previously coastal-only)
All roof-mounted vents must meet testing standards for wind-driven rain prevention

requirements: Steep-roofed structures with asphalt shingles must use products rated 'Excellent' or 'Good' on IBHS Impact-Resistant Shingle Performance Ratings
Provides confidence against hail up to 2 inches diameter

major_2025_changes.update: Many updates relate to changes in ASCE 7 (American Society of Civil Engineers), which FORTIFIED and building codes use for minimum design load requirements

primary_standards_2025.title: Standard Specification for Asphalt Shingles Made from Glass Felt and Surfaced with Mineral Granules
primary_standards_2025.scope: Primary product standard for asphalt roofing shingles
primary_standards_2025.covers: Glass felt shingles impregnated and coated with asphalt, surfaced with mineral granules

primary_standards_2025.title: Standard Specification for Class A Asphalt Shingles Surfaced with Mineral Granules
primary_standards_2025.scope: Secondary product standard providing Class A fire resistance and wind resistance testing

primary_standards_2025.title: Standard Test Method for Wind Resistance of Steep Slope Roofing Products (Fan-Induced Method)
primary_standards_2025.use: Permitted for shingles WITHOUT self-sealing strips

primary_standards_2025.title: Standard Test Method for Wind Resistance of Asphalt Shingles (Uplift Force/Uplift Resistance Method)
primary_standards_2025.scope: Required by IBC/IRC for factory-applied self-sealing strip shingles

primary_standards_2025.title: Standard Test Method for Granule Adhesion to Mineral-Surfaced Roofing by Abrasion
Standard Test Methods for Sampling, Testing, and Analysis of Asphalt Roll Roofing, Cap Sheets, and Shingles
primary_standards_2025.scope: Comprehensive testing methodology for asphalt roofing products

primary_standards_2025.title: Standard Specification for Driven Fasteners: Nails, Spikes, and Staples
primary_standards_2025.scope: Referenced in IRC for fastener compliance

testing_requirements: Physical requirements (tear strength, wind resistance, fire resistance, softening point, pliability) measured immediately after packaging
Products should be tested as soon as possible after manufacturing
Test methods must follow ASTM specifications for validity

for_contractors: Verify local jurisdiction amendments before citing code requirements
Stay current on FORTIFIED certification if operating in FORTIFIED-eligible areas
Maintain GAF Master Elite status for enhanced warranty offerings
Document all installations per manufacturer specs for warranty validity
Be aware of Maryland Bulletin 25-10 when disputing aerial imagery assessments
for_homeowners: Request warranty registration within 45 days of GAF installation
Understand that 2+ layer roofs in PA require complete tear-off
Maryland residents: cite Bulletin 25-10 if insurer uses only aerial imagery for cancellation
Consider FORTIFIED designation for insurance premium reductions
Verify contractor licensing and insurance before signing contracts
for_insurance_adjusters: Comply with Maryland Bulletin 25-10 for aerial imagery use
Review Maryland §27-303 for unfair settlement practices
Understand wind coverage limitations in GAF warranties
Recognize FORTIFIED designation criteria for premium adjustments
Stay updated on local code adoptions affecting repair requirements
